results.title: The Colonies and Britain
results.creator_credit: Colonial Office and Crown Film Unit
results.brief_description: Shows the part played by Britain in making her colonies, particularly those in Africa, technically and economically ready for self-government. Illustrates how the Colonial Office is taking measures in Africa to fight disease, plague and ignorance, how the valuable resources of the colonies are being surveyed and how the necessary technical equipment is being supplied to develop these resources for the benefit of the peoples of the area.

results.title: The Codling moth
results.creator_credit: J.V. Durden, Stephen Ackroyd and Shell Film Unit
results.brief_description: A detailed study of the life cycle of the Codling Moth: the laying and hatching of the eggs; the larva burrowing to the centre of an apple and feeding; larva leaving the infected fruit for hibernation; spinning of the cocoon; changes taking place in the pupal stage; emergence of the adult moth. A diagrammatic section summarises the main stages of the life cycle. No narration, only music.

results.title: The Coal question
results.creator_credit: Tony Chenn, Nicholas Alexander and CSIRO
results.brief_description: There are many questions raised about how coal, Australia’s major export earner, can be used most effectively and most responsibly. This film looks at the role of science in confronting these questions and describes the efforts and results of researchers in areas such as mine safety, coal to oil conversion and pollution control systems.

results.title: The Clubhouse boat
results.brief_description: This film tells of the plight of some young boys whose desire to purchase a boat leads them to commit misdemeanours in order to collect sufficient funds. The story explores the conflicts of loyalty and honesty that arise in the various situations experienced by individuals in the group in their attempts to find cash in a hurry. The story deliberately has no ending so that audiences can make up their own choices and decisions for an appropriate ending.

results.title: The Club
results.creator_credit: Kirk Wong, Richard K. Cheung and Bang Bang Films
results.brief_description: A Triad gang in charge of a popular club fights to keep it from falling into a rival gang’s hands. Along with films by directors such as Tsui Hark and Ringo Lam, “The Club” was one of the first films of the “Hong Kong new wave”. It stood apart from other action films of the time due to its gritty realism and raw violence. Most of the major actors (including the lead Chan Wai Man) were current or former Triad members, and Wong took great pains to film in actual locations, even going so far as to securing “protection” from local gangs. Wong’s filming style, which took on an almost documentary-like quality, also stood apart from the colorful, fanciful films being produced in Hong Kong in the early eighties. He went on to make ‘Crime Story’ (1993) starring Jackie Chan and ‘The Big Hit’ in Hollywood in 1998. In Mandarin with English subtitles.

results.title: The Clown of God (K)
results.creator_credit: Gary McGivney, Ernest Troost, Morton Schindel and Weston Woods Studios
results.brief_description: A beautifully filmed adaptation of the Tomi de Paola story about Giovanni, the clown who juggled for a living during the Middle Ages. Now, old and penniless, he returns to his birthplace seeking refuge in the church on Christmas Eve. Watching the procession of gifts for the Holy Child, he offers the only gift he has - one last performance. Suitable for middle and upper primary level.

results.title: The Cline Affair (TEFC)
results.brief_description: Brings into sharp focus the difficult ethical and moral questions surrounding the burgeoning field of genetic manipulation. The intrigue which cloaked the affair is investigated and the uncertain future of gene therapy is examined

results.title: The Clay circus
results.creator_credit: Herman J. Engel and Texture Films
results.brief_description: Captures, without narration, the spirit of the circus. A clay sculpture, by Shay Rieger, inspired by the color, forms, and motions of the circus, are intercut with segments of actual circus acts.
